title: Registration and Screening
desc: Begin your blood donation journey by registering at the donation center. After registration, you'll undergo a health screening to ensure you meet eligibility criteria. This includes a brief medical history review and vital sign checks, such as blood pressure and hemoglobin levels.

title: Donation
desc: Once you've been cleared for donation, you'll be guided to a comfortable donation area. A trained phlebotomist will gently insert a sterile needle into a vein, typically in your arm, to collect blood. The donation process usually takes about 10-15 minutes.

title: Post-Donation Rest
desc: After your donation, you'll be encouraged to rest for a short period to ensure you're feeling well. Refreshments, including water, juice, and snacks, are often provided to help you recover and maintain your energy.

title: Monitoring and Recovery
desc: You'll be monitored for a brief period to ensure you don't experience any adverse reactions. It's common for donors to feel a bit lightheaded or dizzy after donation, but these feelings typically subside quickly. Once you're feeling well, you can resume your normal activities, including work and exercise.

title: Impact and Repeat Donations
desc: Donated blood is used for various medical procedures, surgeries, and to treat medical conditions, saving lives in the process. You can make a difference in your community by following guidelines for repeat donations and continuing to contribute to the well-being of others.
